title.narrative: Phase I: Emergency Water Supply for Populations in Newly Liberated Areas (NLA) of Mosul East Bank, Ninewa Governorate.

description.narrative: HRF has always selected beneficiaries for WASH programmes based on their need and their availability regardless of their religious, ethnic and/or political backgrounds. In consultation with the Mohktars, the most vulnerable residents of Mosul’s NLA`s were selected.

Mosul, Iraq’s second largest city came under siege by ISIS in 2014. By October 2016, the Iraq Special Forces in a joint effort with the coalition forces, were involved in a military offensive that saw parts of Mosul, largely the eastern side of the city, retaken. This provided both devastation and increased humanitarian access for residents living in Mosul. The devastation brought about the collapse of the entire water network, that had once provided free, clean water to over 600,000 people occupying the east of Mosul city. To ensure the Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) needs of Mosul residents were met after the outbreak of conflict in October 2016, HRF was one of the first to respond in December of the same year.

The emergency water delivery programme is three-fold, based; there is first an immediate response that HRF will provide (water tankers to children and families in Mosul’s NLAs). Second, HRF will cut back on the cost of water tankers whilst it installs temporary static water distribution points (tanks) within the targeted NLAs of Mosul, for use by the population, ensuring Value-for- Money (VfM), and phasing out, within days, of using water tanker from afar afield as Mosul, and rather areas within 15-40km (Khazna and Al-Salamia, respectively). Running in parallel to this, HRF will see the (access), repair/installation of boreholes, water tanks and piping to get Mosul residents provided with safe, clean, accessible water. This forms part and parcel of the third modality, which is to see the activation of both the Khazna water system, 15km east of Mosul City.

name.narrative: In the original proposal and Partnership Agreement 10 NLAs were identified. Due to the continued escalation of the emergency this was scaled up to 17 NLAs.
